# Introduction

![](images/palmer_penguins.png)

In this report, we explore the Palmer Penguins data-set, which contains measurements of penguins from three species observed on islands in Antarctica.

We will:

-   Inspect the structure of the data

-   Summarize key variables

-   Visualize GPA-like outcomes using a boxplot (body mass by species)

# Data preview

First 6 rows

```{r}
head(penguins)
```

## Data Wrangling

Some variables contain missing values.\

For this analysis, we will focus on observations with non-missing body mass.

```{r}
penguins_clean <- penguins %>%
filter(!is.na(body_mass_g))

head(penguins_clean[,c("species", "body_mass_g")])
```

## Summary Statistics

Letâ€™s compute the average body mass by species.

```{r}
penguins_clean %>%
group_by(species) %>%
summarize(
mean_body_mass = mean(body_mass_g),
sd_body_mass   = sd(body_mass_g),
individuals = n()
)

```

## Visualization: Body Mass by Species

We now visualize the distribution of body mass for each penguin species using a **boxplot**.

```{r}
ggplot(penguins_clean,
aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g)) +
geom_boxplot(fill = "skyblue") +
labs(
title = "Distribution of Penguin Body Mass by Species",
x = "Species",
y = "Body Mass (grams)"
) +
theme_minimal()

```

# Message to communicate:

Gentoo species have highest body mass.

*What else?*
